sense.def: Province located in a butalmapu or principality in the Mapuche territory
The four principalities of the Mapuche territory, from the Mapudungun term fütalmapu or "great land"
Need definition
a municipal council in colonial Spanish America (translate def into spanish)
a municipal council in colonial Spanish America
Native indigenous chief- name given to all indigenous peoples of the Spanish empire by the Spanish. The correct technial name for a Mapuche chief is: Lonko (translate def into spanish)
Native indigenous chief: this term was used by the Spanish for chiefs of all indigenous peoples of the Spanish empire; the correct technical name for a Mapuche chief is Lonko
A subordinate of a Cacique
A subordinate of a cacique

form.orth: Comisario de Naciones y Lengua General

sense.def: 1, 2 According to the historian, José Manuel Zavala, this individual is "a representative of the governor….before the Mapuche." He understands and speaks the Mapuche language, understands their ways, and the Mapuche have confidence in this individual. (J.M. Zavala et al. (eds.), The Hispanic-Mapuche Parlamentos: Interethnic Geo-Politics and Concessionary Spaces in Colonial America, Ch. 5, p.78, footnote 10.) (translate def into spanish)

form.orth: General Commissioner of Nations and Language

sense.def: "a representative of the governor… before the Mapuche" who speaks the Mapuche language, understands their culture, and in whom the Mapuche have confidence (J.M. Zavala et al. (eds.), The Hispanic-Mapuche Parlamentos: Interethnic Geo-Politics and Concessionary Spaces in Colonial America, Ch. 5, p.78, footnote 10.)

2 refers to the name of a Franciscan missionary school in the city of Chillán. The goal of the Franciscan friars at this school was to educate and administer the Catholic faith to those who attended, which included children of prominent Pehuenche caciques. (translate def into spanish)

a Franciscan missionary school in the city of Chillán. The goal of the Franciscan friars at this school was to educate and administer the Catholic faith to those who attended, which included children of prominent Pehuenche caciques

a mountain chain; in the Chilean context, the Andes Mountains, which form the eastern border of Chile
A garment of a type originally worn in South America, made of thick piece of woolen cloth with a slit in the middle for the head (translate def into spanish)
A garment of a type originally worn in South America, made of thick piece of woolen cloth with a slit in the middle for the head

A military occupation of Mapuche lands which dispossessed and resettled Mapuche peoples from their territory and moved them onto government approved territorial allotments called reducciones, literally reductions (translate def into spanish)

When capitalized: used to describe a European nation, typically Spain.
When not capitalized: used to describe a polity not recognized by the Spaniards as a fully legitimate nation-state, e.g. the Mapuche.

when capitalized, typically indicates a European or other independent nation; when not capitalized, typically indicates a polity not recognized by the Spaniards as a fully legitimate nation-state, e.g. the Mapuche

a senior priest connected to a cathedral, who may act as the bishop's commissary
a gathering or meeting; often used interchangeably with Parlamento
the highest-ranking clergyman in a diocese, typically the bishop
(of a priest): appointed by the bishop to serve a particular church
from the Latin 'gremio ecclesiae', or 'lap/bosom of the Church', an extension of the ancient depiction of the Church as a mother
a high-ranking Mapuche leader; a Spanish term that may be used to refer to the Cacique of a Butalmapu, or to members of a Cacique's inner circle, or to the Mapuche leader of a Reduction
